bounties.name: Function for determining Operator equality
bounties.title: Function for determining Operator equality
bounties.body:
In order to determine if two `Operator`'s are equal, we currently have to manually compare different properties like:

```python
assert op1.__class__ is op2.__class__
assert all( qml.math.allclose(d1, d2) for d1, d2 in zip(op1.data, op2.data))
assert op1.wires == op2.wires
for kwarg in op1.hyperparameters:
    assert op1.hyperparameters[kwarg] == op2.hyperparameters[kwarg]
```

We currently don't want to override the dunder magic method `__eq__`, so we want a new function `qml.equal` that determines the equality of two operations. By using a function, we can also have control over what "equal" exactly means.

This function should be located in a new file`pennylane/ops/functions/equal.py`.

The function should take two arguments `op1` and `op2`.

The function can also accept a number of keyword arguments:
* `rtol=1e-5`: relative tolerance for equality for numerical data;
* `atol=1e-9`: absolute tolerance for equality for numerical data;
* `equal_interface=True`: whether or not parameters of different interfaces are considered equal. The keyword name is not fixed;
* `equal_trainability=True`: whether parameters marked as trainable should be equal to parameters marked as non-trainable. The keyword name is not fixed.

```pycon
>>> op1 = qml.RX(torch.tensor(1.2), wires=0)
>>> op2 = qml.RX(jax.numpy.array(1.2), wires=0)
>>> qml.equal(op1, op2)
False
>>> qml.equal(op1, op2, equal_interface=False)
True

>>> op3 = qml.RX(np.array(1.2, requires_grad=True), wires=0)
>>> op4 = qml.RX(np.array(1.2, requires_grad=False), wires=0)
>>> qml.equal(op3, op4)
False
>>> qml.equal(op3, op4, equal_trainability=False)
True
```

This new function should also be tested in a new file `./tests/ops/functions/test_equal.py`. There should be a test case for all parametrized operations in PennyLane making sure that `qml.equal` works as expected (`pytest`'s `parametrize` can help here with brevity).

For objects that inherit from `Observable` like Pauli Operators, `Tensor`, `Hermitian`, and `Hamiltonian`, we can defer to `op1.compare(op2)`.

bounties.name: Request for new matplotlib drawing styles
bounties.title: Request for new matplotlib drawing styles
bounties.body:
## Introduction and Motivation

PennyLane currently has three in-built styles for use with our matplotlib circuit drawer:
* `"default"`
* `"black_white"`
* `"black_white_dark"`

See the documentation for these styles [on the `qml.drawer` page](https://pennylane.readthedocs.io/en/stable/code/qml_drawer.html#styling-matplotlib-circuit-graphics). These styles work by setting [matplotlib's `rcParams`](https://matplotlib.org/stable/tutorials/introductory/customizing.html) dictionary.  

We welcome contributors to submit new styles.

Each style should update the `plt.rcParams` configuration to make **clean** and **readable** circuit diagram graphics.  Creating a new style is more about visual design than any coding.

I can offer the [Solarized color scheme](https://ethanschoonover.com/solarized/) and [matplotlib's xkcd style](https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.xkcd.html) as inspiration.

## Code requirements

To add a new style:

* add a private function to [`pennylane/drawer/style.py`](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/pennylane/drawer/style.py)
* Decorate this function with `@_needs_mpl`
* Add the name of the style and it's function to the `_styles_map` dictionary
* Add a test to [`tests/drawer/test_style.py`](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/tests/drawer/test_style.py)
* Run [`doc/_static/style/style_examples.py`](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/doc/_static/style/style_examples.py) to generate a png demonstrating the new style
*  Update [`doc/code/qml_drawer.rst`](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/doc/code/qml_drawer.rst) so that it also displays the new style in the "Currently Available Styles" section. Note that displaying images side-by-side with rst can be tricky.

bounties.name: Adding IsingXY operation
bounties.title: Adding `IsingXY` operation
bounties.body:
### **Context**

We would like to define a new operation called IsingXY, as [defined in the PennyLane-Braket plugin](https://amazon-braket-pennylane-plugin-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/code/api/braket.pennylane_plugin.XY.html).

### **Steps to take**

 **Adding the operation**

- Adding the IsingXY class and its attributes to `pennylane/ops/qubit/parametric_ops.py`. 
- Complete its docstring in a similar fashion as for other operations. Make sure the class is accessible through qml.IsingXY.
- Add its decomposition, matrix, eigenvalues, adjoint and generator.
- Make sure the operation works with parameters from all interfaces (autograd, torch, tensorflow and jax)


**Adding devices support**

- Add support for the operation in the `default.qubit` and `default.mixed` devices

**Testing**

- Add the matrix to `pennylane/tests/gate_data.py`
- Test the gate itself
- Test the gradients with multiple interfaces (autograd, torch, tensorflow and jax) with an **analytical** formula.

### **Notes**

You can refer to the implementation and testings of `IsingXX`, `IsingYY` and `IsingZZ`.

As an example, here is the [implementation](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/pennylane/ops/qubit/parametric_ops.py#L2246) and [the testing of the decomposition](https://github.com/PennyLaneAI/pennylane/blob/master/tests/ops/qubit/test_parametric_ops.py#L307) for the `IsingYY` operation. The linked test file contains further test cases for `IsingYY`.

We would like to have a separate `requirements_dev.txt` file located top level, that gathers all the requirements required for developing PennyLane.

The file should contain the following packages, all with a permissive `>=` pinning:
```
pre-commit
pytest
pytest-cov
pytest-mock
pytest-xdist
flaky
black>=21
```
The requirement of `black` should be removed from the `requirements.txt`.

### Implementation

* Creating a new `requirements_dev.txt` file;
* Mentioning that developers new to PennyLane can use the `requirements_dev.txt` file in the [Ways to contribute to the PennyLane repository section](https://pennylane.readthedocs.io/en/stable/development/guide/contributing.html#ways-to-contribute-to-the-pennylane-repository) for contributing to PennyLane.

### How important would you say this feature is?

2: Somewhat important. Needed this quarter.

### Additional information

_No response_

bounties.body: ANTLR released a new version, 4.10, on 11 April 2022. This release breaks the augmented transition network (ATN) serialized state machine in the generated code from earlier versions. The [4.10 Release notes](https://github.com/antlr/antlr4/releases/tag/4.10) explain that they broke the serializer format and the generated code needs to be regenerated with the 4.10 tooling and the python dep needs to be set to 4.10+

bounties.name: pyqir-evaluator should gracefully fail when bitcode contains unknown external functions
bounties.title: pyqir-evaluator should gracefully fail when bitcode contains unknown external functions
bounties.body:
**Describe the bug**

When an LLVM file contains declarations of external functions that are unknown, the evaluator crashes without displaying an error message or raising an Exception.

Issue related to #121.

**To Reproduce**

Use an LLVM file that contains unknown external functions, such as:

```
%String = type opaque

declare %String* @__quantum__rt__bool_to_string(i1)

define void @main() #1 {
entry:
  call %String* @__quantum__rt__bool_to_string(i1 1)
  ret void
}

attributes #1 = { "EntryPoint" }
```

This evaluation does not reach the end and throws no Exception:
```
from pyqir.evaluator import GateLogger, NonadaptiveEvaluator

print("Start")

try:
    NonadaptiveEvaluator().eval("CrashMe.ll", GateLogger())
except Exception as e:
    print("An exception was raised.")

print("End")
```

**Expected behavior**

The evaluator should either:
* Handle them in a transparent manner (if possible)
* Display an error message ("Unsupported function...")
* Raise an exception

bounties.name: Allow plugin loading to fail gracefully.
bounties.title: Allow plugin loading to fail
bounties.body: I think we should allow plugins to fail and if they do just throw a warning and continue loading the rest of the plugins. No reason that a plugin failing to load should mean you can't use the framework at all.

bounties.name: Flexible instruction simulation
bounties.title: Flexible Instruction Simulation
bounties.body:
Currently, most simulators leverage the AllGateVisitor to walk the IR tree and apply correct gate unitaries to a state vector. Instructions are a plugin to the framework, so if someone introduces a new Instruction, then all these simulators and AllGateVisitor need to be updated to add a visit() method for that new Instruction.

It would be interesting to see if we could come up with a way such that if one provides a new Instruction, they could also provide the matrix representation via some other plugin interface, and hook up AllGateVisitor to by default try to extract an unknown Instructions matrix data and use it as part of the simulation.

bounties.name: Implement 3-qubit decomposition
bounties.title: Implement 3-qubit decomposition
bounties.body:
Similar to our existing KAK decomposition for 2-q unitary matrices, we can also implement the deterministic 3-q decomposition as a XACC `Circuit` class.

Ref: https://github.com/quantumlib/Cirq/blob/master/cirq-core/cirq/optimizers/three_qubit_decomposition.py
It's simple enough to have a native implementation rather than requiring Cirq dependency.

This should also benefit other high-level decomposition by optimization since we can decompose to bigger blocks.

bounties.name: Automatic packaging
bounties.title: Automatic packaging
bounties.body:
Once #362 goes through, it would be nice to have some automatic packaging routine and some CI test on it.

The packaging process is a bit unorthodox because we have three different PyPI distributions under the same repository:
- `pulser-core`, which contains the `pulser` package
- `pulser-simulation`, which contains the `pulser_simulation` package
- `pulser`, which has no package in itself but installs a specific version of `pulser-core` and `pulser-simulation`

AFAIK, [`cirq`](https://github.com/quantumlib/Cirq) has a similar setup, so it might be worth looking into for inspiration.

bounties.name: Automatize docstrings types
bounties.title: Automatize docstrings types
bounties.body:
Currently, functions' parameters and return types are precised in the docstrings. It is redundant, because they are already given as typehints.

```python
    @_store
    def target(
        self,
        qubits: Union[QubitId, Iterable[QubitId], Parametrized],
        channel: str,
    ) -> None:
        """Changes the target qubit of a 'Local' channel.

        Args:
            qubits (Union[int, str, Iterable]): The new target for this
                channel. Must correspond to a qubit ID in device or an iterable
                of qubit IDs, when multi-qubit addressing is possible.
            channel (str): The channel's name provided when declared. Must be
                a channel with 'Local' addressing.
        """
```

It would be great to remove these repetitions, by automatically inferring the types in the docs from the typehints. We might for example try to use the library https://github.com/tox-dev/sphinx-autodoc-typehints for that purpose.

bounties.name: Changing the device of a Sequence
bounties.title: Changing the device of a Sequence
bounties.body:
It might be useful to switch the device of an already constructed sequence.

Off the top of my head, I can think of two main features here:
- Compatibility with the new device of each element in the sequence's schedule. This would be easier if the validation methods currently residing in `Sequence` were moved to the `Device` class, where the constraints reside.
- A systematic matching between the channels of different devices.

bounties.name: More flexible sequence drawing
bounties.title: More flexible sequence drawing
bounties.body:
Currently, sequence drawing always has a curve for amplitude and another for detuning, in spite of the fact that detuning is sometimes not used and thus could be omitted. 
On the other hand, jumps in phase could be something that would be useful to track, especially considering that it is also affected by channel modulation.

The idea here is to enable the drawing function to assess which quantities and adapt accordingly. It will require a bit of refactoring because the drawing function is currently built around the fact that the number of subplots per channel is fixed, which will no longer be the case.

bounties.name: Add thumbnail images to documentation examples
bounties.title: Add thumbnail images to documentation examples.
bounties.body:
Issue Description
-----------------

Currently we have thumbnail images only for a fraction of the examples in the docs: https://mitiq.readthedocs.io/en/v0.15.0/examples/examples.html

It would be good to have thumbnail images for all examples.


Proposed Solution
-----------------

There are different ways of adding thumbnail images with sphinx gallery:

- Adding an hard-coded image, not necessarily plots produced by the associated example. 
- Using a self-generated plot produced by the example during the docs build.
- Adding an hard-coded image of a plot generated by the example. This may be useful for zooming or other image edits.

Any option is fine. What is important is having a final result that looks good and clear.

For an example a gallery that looks good see, e.g.,  https://pennylane.ai/qml/demonstrations.html

bounties.name: Include backend in execute_with_shots
bounties.title: [unitaryhack-bounty] Include backend option for real hardware in mitiq.interface.mitiq_qiskit.qiskit_utils.execute_with_shots
bounties.body:
Pre-Request Checklist
---------------------

- [X ] I checked to make sure that this feature has not already been requested.

Issue Description
-----------------
Currently the function execute_with_shots or execute_with_shots_and_noise do not allow for specific backend, e.g real hardware rather than simulator or different noise model from the simulator, so the calculation of the expectation value requires specifies a circuit with different basis measurement X, Y, Z, etc when the Hamiltonian is complex. 

Proposed Solution
-----------------

It would be nice to allow real backend input in the qiskit_utils.execute_with_shots in the qiskit interface so it's a lot easier to calculate the expectation value of an operator.

bounties.name: Improve H2 example
bounties.title: [unitaryhack-bounty] Improve H2 example
bounties.body:
The current H2 example could be improved in two different aspects:

- [ ] The numerical values of the Hamiltonian coefficients _g_j(R)_ are hard-coded from data extracted from a paper. It would be nice to derive them using some chemistry package e.g.: [PySCF](https://pyscf.org/) or [OpenFermion](https://github.com/quantumlib/OpenFermion). Ideally (but only if not too complicated), it would be better to use the same Hamiltonian in order to reproduce the same results of the Mitiq paper. 
- [ ] Use a `mitiq.Observable` for the Hamiltonian, and just use `mitiq_cirq.compute_density_matrix` for the executor. See the docs for more details on how to define and use observables.

If you only fixed one of the two aspects, please don't close this issue but just mark the corresponding item in the above list.

bounties.name: Adding coherence time calculations to scqubits GUI
bounties.title: Adding coherence time calculations to scqubits GUI
bounties.body:
This issue is meant as a unitaryHACK bounty issue.
**Bounty**: $75

Some of the functionality of scqubits can be easily explored via it's jupyter-widgets-based GUI, which is discussed [here](https://scqubits.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/ipynb/gui.html).

We would like to extend this GUI functionality to include plots of the estimated coherence times. 

Coherence time calculations are already implemented for various qubits, as is explained in the [documentation](https://scqubits.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/guide-noise.html).

We envision for the updated GUI to, at the very least, for each qubit, show the [effective](https://scqubits.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/noise/ipynb/visualization.html#Effective-coherence-time-calculations) coherence time plotted versus the parameter that is being scanned-over.   

Using default coherence calculation parmaters would be a good start, although a more desirable outcome would allow users some flexibility. For example allowing users to select what noise channels should be included in the coherence time estimation, and/or allowing them to set some non-default options for each, would be welcome.

bounties.name: Creation of a new jupyter notebook tutorial
bounties.title: Creation of a new jupyter notebook tutorial
bounties.body:
This issue is meant as a unitaryHACK bounty issue.
**Bounty**: $75

We would like to make scqubits easier to use by providing more involved tutorials that describe its various features. Some of these are already present in this [repository](https://github.com/scqubits/scqubits-examples) and can be explored interactively [here](https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/scqubits/scqubits-examples/released).

The new jupyter notebook tutorial should present examples of interfacing scqubits with qutip. 

This could include: 
- building a composite system (e.g., a fluxonium qubit coupled to resonator)
- calculating some relevant drive operators in the dressed basis of the composite system (e.g. charge operator, for the resonator and/or the fluxonium)  
- using the effective Hamiltonian and relevant drive operator in qutip's `mesolve` or `sesolve` to study the evolution of the system being subject to some reasonable time-dependent pulses (that should, for example, result in a gate).

A more involved example could include doing some evolution as part of a custom ParameterSweep (see "Custom Sweeps" section of [this](https://github.com/scqubits/scqubits-examples/blob/master/examples/demo_parametersweep.ipynb) notebook for ideas). 

The final jupyter notebook tutorial should be added to [this](https://github.com/scqubits/scqubits-examples) examples/tutorials repository.

bounties.name: Font scaling in labels of plot.matrix2d()
bounties.title: Font scaling in labels of plot.matrix2d()
bounties.body:
This issue is meant as a unitaryHACK bounty issue.
**Bounty**: $50

Function `plot.matrix2d()` is used when creating matrix element plots (it is called by qubit methods `<qubit>.plot_matrixelements()`). It has an argument `show_numbers` which explicitly adds text labels to indicate matrix element sizes. This example below shows how that works: 

    tmon2 = scq.Transmon(
        EJ=30.02,
        EC=1.2,
        ng=0.0,
        ncut=31
    )
    tmon.plot_matrixelements('cos_phi_operator', evals_count=10, show3d=False, show_numbers=True);

When too many levels are included, however, these labels start overlapping with each other, as in:

    tmon.plot_matrixelements('cos_phi_operator', evals_count=16, show3d=False, show_numbers=True);

We are looking for a small enhancement that adds simple logic to `plot.matrix2d()` which would scale the font size so that the text labels can be easily distinguished (within reason).
Ideally this modification should take into account the figure size, so that if more levels are being included, but the figure size is large enough, then the font used does not have to be extremely small.

bounties.name: Enhancement of the plot_transitions() method
bounties.title: Enhancement of the plot_transitions() method
bounties.body:
This issue is meant as a unitaryHACK bounty issue.
**Bounty**: $50

`plot_transitions()` is a method of class `ParameterSweepBase` which can be used for plotting energies associated with various transitions as a function of a scanned parameter. An example of how it can be used is presented [here](https://scqubits.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/ipynb/paramsweep2.html#Transition-plot-options).
 
We are looking to add an enhancement where one can pass lists of tuples as arguments `initial` and/or `final`, with **specific** state labels that represent initial and final transition end-points of transitions that should be plotted. So for example calling:

        sweep.plot_transitions(initial=[(1,2,4), (1,3,1)], final=[(0,1,0)])

should lead to (only) transitions between levels with labels (1,2,4)<->(0,1,0) and (1,3,1)<->(0,1,0) being plotted. 

These changes should not break current code, and should be documented in the method's docstring.

(It would of course be great, if this addition would be also briefly explained in the [documentation](https://github.com/scqubits/scqubits-doc) - but that is not part of the bounty).

bounties.name: Check URL validity for image and content URLs on submission

bounties.name: Scirate ‘Scite!’ counts for submission
bounties.title: “As a user, I want to see Scirate ‘Scite!’ counts, so that I have an index of general academic social media statistics for Metriq content.”
bounties.body:
### User <-> Web App
User System (Web app)
1. (User on single submission view) 1. (Displaying homepage)
2. 2. "Scite!" button is displayed blow the submission abstract.
3. User looks at the "Scite!" button to determine if submision contains information from Scirate. 3.
4. 4. IF: The single submission view contains an arXiv URL, a number is displayed next to "Scite!" ELSE: The "Scite!" button is displayed with no number
5. (User sees how many scites there are for submission) 5. (Number of scites for submission displayed on button if applicable.
### User <-> REST API
User System (REST API)
1. Call REST API: GET ./api/submissions:/{uuid}/scites 1.
2. IF `submissionContentUrl` has arXiv prefix (in `Submission.js`) call to Scirate Python client to retrieve scite count. ELSE: Return NULL 2.
3. (Successful call) 3. (Successful response)
### Questions: Can we use this [Scirate parser](https://github.com/vprusso/scirate) to use the extracted information? Some concerns are: - Our API is Javascript and the parser is in Python. We'd need some way for these to talk to each other. - CSRF may prevent us from obtaining information from a script and then displaying it on our site? ### Alternate approach: Ask Scirate devs if they are able to supply API access to their website to directly extract this information. ### Related issues to this story: - [ ] https://github.com/unitaryfund/metriq-app/issues/159 - [ ] https://github.com/unitaryfund/metriq-app/issues/158

bounties.name: Given an operator (matrix) determine if it is block-positive
bounties.title: Feature: Is block-positive
bounties.body:
Given an operator (matrix) determine if it is block-positive. 

The definition of block-positivity can be found in Section 2.2.5 in [arXiv:1207.1479](https://arxiv.org/abs/1207.1479).

Determining block-positivity is a very useful tool in the context of quantum state discrimination. Such an example application can be found in [arXiv:1408.6981](https://arxiv.org/abs/1408.6981). Roughly speaking, the utility is because the cone of block-positive operators constitutes the dual cone of separable operators--and hence determining block-positivity can be useful for proving separability results for certain quantum state discrimination schemes. 

An implementation of determining whether an operator is block-positive can be found in [QETLAB's `IsBlockPositive` function](http://www.qetlab.com/IsBlockPositive). This will be a useful reference implementation to test against. 

Will require feature that allows computing the S(k) norm

https://github.com/vprusso/toqito/issues/73

to be completed as a pre-requisite.

bounties.name: Implement NPA hierarchhy for extended nonlocal games
bounties.title: Feature: NPA hierarchy for extended nonlocal games
bounties.body:
Task: Implement the NPA hierarchy for extended nonlocal games. 

The NPA hierarchy is used as a bounding technique to approximate upper bounds on the quantum value of a nonlocal game. Extended nonlocal games are a superset of nonlocal games, and an analogous concept (referred to as the "extended NPA hierarchy") exists to upper bound the quantum value of any extended nonlocal game. 

More information on nonlocal games and extended nonlocal games can be found in the respective `toqito` tutorials [here](https://toqito.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials.nonlocal_games.html) and [here](https://toqito.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials.html#extended-nonlocal-games). More information about the extended NPA hierarchy can be found in chapter 5 or [this thesis](https://vprusso.github.io/pdf/thesis.pdf).

Presently, `toqito` implements the NPA hierarchy for nonlocal games. Adapting this feature for extended nonlocal games would most likely require building on top of the functionality found in `helper/npa_hierarchy.py`.

More information on the NPA hierarchy and the manner in which this idea is encoded into `toqito` can be found in the lecture [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vJV3DWvuVtM) on the NPA hierarchy by John Watrous.

bounties.name: Calculate Schmidt decomposition of density matrix
bounties.title: Feature: Determine Schmidt decomposition of density matrix
bounties.body:
There currently exists a function `schmidt_decomposition.py`. Given a vector, the function provides the Schmidt decomposition.

Ideally, this function should include the ability to provide not just the Schmidt decomposition of a vector as input, but be robust enough to handle inputs provided as density matrices as well. 

Consulting and enhancing the `schmidt_decomposition.py` file should be where the aforementioned enhancements should take place.

bounties.name: Determine if density matrix is separable or entangled
bounties.title: Feature: Is separable
bounties.body:
Create a feature `state_props/is_separable.py` that is able to determine whether or not a given state represented as a density matrix is separable or entangled. 

In general, this problem is NP-hard. However, there are a number of entanglement detection tests that act as more effective heuristics that can be run on the state in question first before getting to computing the NP-hard problem. As the problem is NP-hard, it will become intractable for certain quantum states, but in practice, should be relatively effective at determining the property of the state.

bounties.name: A true, better code graph
bounties.title: Revamp the code graph
bounties.body:
The current code graph page was written pretty hastily; it consists of a patchwork of JS code using web-ready libraries to plot the graph and offers no user-friendly means of navigating the graph.

I'd like to revamp the code graph page into a proper JS Web Application with a much more robust infrastructure and with a significantly higher user experience quality.

Requirements:
- A React-based JS web application, bundled along with other JS code into the zoo site using webpack (see the `jscomponents/` folder)
- I'm anticipating that the [*cytoscape* JS library](https://js.cytoscape.org/) should be used to generate the code graph
- Relationships between the codes should be made visible in an intuitive fashion (e.g., arrows to parents)
- The layout should be generated automatically, and should not require additional meta-information to be input in individual EC codes.
- The input to the app is a data structure representing a collection of EC codes, with meta-information such as name, description, etc., as well as references to parents, children, and cousins.

Some ideas that might require some design decisions:
- I'd like a user-friendly experience for navigating different parts of the graph. This might include some UI controls to zoom/pan the graph, to show/hide certain types of relationships, etc.
- Perhaps at the highest zoom level, we shouldn't display individual codes, but rather, "boxes" or some other visual effect placeholder to represent a family of codes (e.g., qubit codes). Ideas are welcome for how to meaningfully represent the information in an intuitive way at different zoom levels.
- The code graph will need more information than the bare meta-information given in the input data structure. E.g., it will want to build "code families", given for instance by collecting all codes that are a descendant of a given code. I'd like for such pre-processing code to be in a separate component/library, in anticipation for possible use also in other parts of the site generation process. (For background information, I'm eyeing a move of the entire site generation code from python to javascript.)
- The app's code should be sufficiently modular and make sufficiently few hypotheses about the code structure, in that I'd like it to be possible to generate a code graphs separately on other site pages, too, with a subset of the entire EC codes database. For instance, on the page of the parent "topological code", it would be nice to be able to generate a "local graph" of all topological codes (ignoring all other codes).

Optional:
- Any further ideas to make the browsing experience better are welcome!

bounties.name: Make QCOR QIR Compatible with QAT
bounties.title: Make QCOR QIR Compatible with QIR Alliance QAT Tool
bounties.body:
I just tried to take a QIR file output from qcor and translate to the base profile with the QAT tool from the QIR Alliance. It did not work out of the box. Turns out, QAT will look for a function attribute and perform the transformation from there. 

From Stefan
```
QAT looks for a specific LLVM attribute to know which function to start it’s processing from. 
This can be either “InteropFriendly” (the default) or “EntryPoint” (selectable with “—entry-point-attr EntryPoint”). 
Then the IR needs to be updated to have that attribute on exactly one function.
In this case, if I update main to include that attribute, the transformation succeeds.
```

Also there is a discrepancy with our measurement call 
```
One other thing to note: transformation of measurement into the form described in the base profile, 
which uses static result identifiers, is dependent on seeing the intrinsic “__quantum__qis__m__body” 
as the measurement function. That’s why the “__quantum__qis__mz” in the above did not get transformed.
```

bounties.name: Quantum Applications
bounties.title: Quantum Applications [unitaryhack]
bounties.body:
This issue is available during the UnitaryHACK:

**Bounty: $100 and a free PIQUE t-shirt** :1st_place_medal: 

_Note: Teams of 2-5 people are suggested_ :busts_in_silhouette: 

Design a tutorial where you cover one or more of the possible areas: chemistry, machine learning, cryptography, and/or any other applications that can be connected to an important issue in daily life or real world use cases.

You should explain step by step each essential concept to understand the theory of your tutorial, and attach the code as the desired result and the necessary dependencies to be able to run it. You should focus on the educational part and explain each section of the code with references, and in the final part you should add a note about how you got started in this area of quantum computing. The aim is that your project will inspire others :smile: .

If you have a previously made project for another hackathon or school project, please note that this tutorial will be open source and all credits will be given to you, as well as  to get an idea of what we expect as a result, you can check out our website: [fullstackquantumcomputation](https://fullstackquantumcomputation.tech/) :computer: .

If you have doubts about which idea could be useful for your tutorial, we list the following possible tutorials that can be done :bulb: :

- Idea one: Simulating the electronic structure of molecules.
- Idea two: Classification or prediction of a classical or  quantum dataset.
- Idea three: File transfer using a quantum communication protocol.
- Idea four: Optimization to minimize the cost of traffic.
- Idea five: Stock forecasting.

**If you have your own idea, and it follows the above requirements you can use it :smiley:  just reply to this Issue to confirm your idea.**

bounties.name: Implement a succ_full ansatz option
bounties.title: Implement an equivalent to legacy `succ_full` option
bounties.body:
<!-- ⚠️ If you do not respect this template, your issue will be closed -->
<!--tythontho ⚠️ Make sure to browse the opened and closed issues to confirm this idea does not exist. -->

### What is the expected enhancement?

The [legacy `UCCSD`](https://github.com/Qiskit/qiskit-aqua/blob/main/qiskit/chemistry/components/variational_forms/uccsd.py) implementation had a `method_doubles="succ_full"` option which is not yet implemented in Qiskit Nature.
This option is a variant of the (now named) `SUCCD` option which also includes symmetrically mirrored double excitations, however, using the same parameter as the symmetric counter part (as also noted [here](https://github.com/Qiskit/qiskit-nature/blob/aae9c01b4d02bf5dbaa342c757be2cfef60a31d5/qiskit_nature/circuit/library/ansatzes/succd.py#L34-L35)).

The original implementation in Qiskit Aqua came from the work of [this paper](https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.5141835) in which sections II.E.2 and appendix E provide more in-depth information.
The following Qiskit Nature snippet shows the current state of the `SUCCD` ansatz for the example discussed the aforementioned paper's appendix:
```python
from qiskit_nature.circuit.library.ansatzes import SUCCD
from qiskit_nature.converters.second_quantization import QubitConverter
from qiskit_nature.mappers.second_quantization import JordanWignerMapper

converter = QubitConverter(JordanWignerMapper())
ansatz = SUCCD(converter, (1, 1), 6)

print(ansatz.decompose().draw())
print(ansatz.excitation_list)
```
which outputs:
```
     ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐»
q_0: ┤0                                                                                            ├»
     │                                                                                             │»
q_1: ┤1                                                                                            ├»
     │                                                                                             │»
q_2: ┤2                                                                                            ├»
     │  exp(-it (IYYIXY + IXXIXY + IXYIYY + IYXIYY + IXYIXX + IYXIXX + IYYIYX + IXXIYX))(1.0*t[0]) │»
q_3: ┤3                                                                                            ├»
     │                                                                                             │»
q_4: ┤4                                                                                            ├»
     │                                                                                             │»
q_5: ┤5                                                                                            ├»
     └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘»
«     ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐»
«q_0: ┤0                                                                                            ├»
«     │                                                                                             │»
«q_1: ┤1                                                                                            ├»
«     │                                                                                             │»
«q_2: ┤2                                                                                            ├»
«     │  exp(-it (YZYIXY + XZXIXY + XZYIYY + YZXIYY + XZYIXX + YZXIXX + YZYIYX + XZXIYX))(1.0*t[1]) │»
«q_3: ┤3                                                                                            ├»
«     │                                                                                             │»
«q_4: ┤4                                                                                            ├»
«     │                                                                                             │»
«q_5: ┤5                                                                                            ├»
«     └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘»
«     ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
«q_0: ┤0                                                                                            ├
«     │                                                                                             │
«q_1: ┤1                                                                                            ├
«     │                                                                                             │
«q_2: ┤2                                                                                            ├
«     │  exp(-it (YZYXZY + XZXXZY + XZYYZY + YZXYZY + XZYXZX + YZXXZX + YZYYZX + XZXYZX))(1.0*t[2]) │
«q_3: ┤3                                                                                            ├
«     │                                                                                             │
«q_4: ┤4                                                                                            ├
«     │                                                                                             │
«q_5: ┤5                                                                                            ├
«     └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
[((0, 3), (1, 4)), ((0, 3), (1, 5)), ((0, 3), (2, 5))]
```

In this context, the goal of this issue is to implement a variant of `SUCCD` (or an additional keyword argument to its constructor) which results in the inclusion of the `((0, 3), (2, 4))` excitation, while at the same time still using only three parameters (namely `t[0]-t[2]` in the example above). This should be achieved by ensuring that `((0, 3), (1, 5))` and `((0, 3), (2, 4))` are assigned the same parameter (namely `t[1]` in the example above).

bounties.name: Improve performance of mode_based_mapping method in QubitMapper
bounties.title: Improve performance of `QubitMapper.mode_based_mapping`
bounties.body:
### What is the expected enhancement?

When looking towards larger systems and an increased amount of auxiliary operators (multiple hundreds to thousands), the performance of `QubitMapper.mode_based_mapping` becomes a serious bottleneck in the pre-processing step. Waiting times for all auxiliary operators to be mapped can reach on the order of minutes.

I believe, performance can be significantly improved if we:
- cache the processed `pauli_list` object within `QubitMapper` (requires changing the `mode_based_mapping` from a static to an instance method)
- refactor the iteration to deal with sparse labels rather than dense ones (requires sparse labels to be the default, a conversion of dense to sparse, and updating the `VibrationalOp` to be inline with the `FermionicOp` again; if this gets tackled before said update, we can also handle the mapping `FermionicOp`s separately for the time being)
- potentially do something similar to #638 by constructing a single `SparsePauliOp` from a list of terms rather than performing the full computation each time

I put together a script which benchmarks the performance of the mapping.
```python
import time

from matplotlib import pyplot as plt

from qiskit_nature.mappers.second_quantization import JordanWignerMapper
from qiskit_nature.operators.second_quantization import FermionicOp

mapper = JordanWignerMapper()

timings = {}

with open("timings.csv", "w") as file:
    try:
        for size in range(10, 21, 5):
            timings[size] = {}
            for num in range(100, 1001, 100):
                print(f"Mapping {num} operators of length {size}", flush=True)
                start = time.time()
                for i in range(num):
                    q_ops = mapper.map(FermionicOp(" ".join(f"N_{i}" for i in range(size)),
                                                   display_format="sparse"))
                stop = time.time()
                timings[size][num] = stop - start

                file.write(f"{size},{num},{stop - start}\n")
                file.flush()
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        pass
```
This will run for a quite a while on latest `main` @ aae9c01.
Below is the timing report. Right now, this pretty much scales 1-to-1 with the number of operators but I believe we can significantly reduce the overhead.

bounties.name: Official PyQrack Documentation
bounties.title: Official PyQrack Documentation
bounties.body:
PyQrack has no documentation, beyond its README. The reason this can be, despite some hundred thousand downloads worth of utilization by others, is that PyQrack exposes a quantum gate API that is well-known colloquialism; what "`T`" means as a gate name in any quantum computing API is what it means in PyQrack, and so on for most-to-all gates in [`qrack_simulator.py`](https://github.com/vm6502q/pyqrack/blob/main/pyqrack/qrack_simulator.py), basically. This isn't entirely welcoming to new users, though. Many would benefit from a repository of readable API definition, at least.

Work toward formal documentation of PyQrack API can constitute unitaryHACK contribution. I can start a vm6502q organization repository for this, before or during unitaryHACK.

bounties.name: Add support for a single-file HDF5 log
bounties.title: Add support for a single-file HDF5 log
bounties.body:
[This issue is part of [UnitaryHack](https://unitaryhack.dev/) and comes with a bounty of 75$]

## Context

NetKet simulation drivers support output of the current state of an optimization as well as expectation values of observables and custom data via the classes provided in `netket.logging`.

Currently, NetKet has two main logging implementations:

1. [`JsonLog`](https://github.com/netket/netket/blob/master/netket/logging/json_log.py), which is the standard logger and writes log data to a JSON file (and also saves a regularly overwritten snapshot of the current network parameters as a MessagePack file).
2. [`StateLog`](https://github.com/netket/netket/blob/master/netket/logging/state_log.py), which saves intermediate network parameters as a separate file for each step (`1.mpack`, `2.mpack`, `3.mpack`, etc.) to a folder or ZIP file.

While these work, it would be nice for easier data handling and interoperability with other tools to support writing simulation output into a single file in the commonly used [HDF5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_Data_Format) format via [`h5py`](https://docs.h5py.org/en/stable/).

## Implementation notes

To resolve this issue, the following should be implemented:

1. A new logger class `netket.logging.HDF5Log` which writes both the information currently contained in `JsonLog` and the network parameters (at each step or every certain number of steps as it can be configured in `StateLog`) to an HDF5 file specified by the user.
2. The logger needs to be compatible with the current NetKet logging interface, so that it can be used in place of `JsongLog` and `StateLog` in NetKet drivers. (For this PR this means compatibility with the current use of the loggers in [`netket.driver.AbstractVariationalDriver`](https://github.com/netket/netket/blob/master/netket/driver/abstract_variational_driver.py#L56).) Specifically:
    - The logger needs to implement `__call__(self, step, log_data, state)` which is called at [each optimization step](https://github.com/netket/netket/blob/ce60a41328808a6c803e7be63a17d9a54c812b8d/netket/driver/abstract_variational_driver.py#L268) and write the provided data to the HDF5 log file.
    - Since the number of steps (i.e., number of calls to `__call__`) is not known before the start of the simulation, the log must support appending data to the log every at every step (therefore, the datasets within the HDF5 file need to be resized as necessary).

Note that `log_data` is a dictionary mapping a name to a specific logged quantity. The value can be of several different types. The `HDF5Log` should support scalar numbers, NumPy/JAX arrays, and `netket.stats.Stats` objects.

- Scalars should be stored as a group with one dataset `values` of shape `(n_steps,)` containing the logged values and another dataset `iters` of the same shape containing the value of `step` at which each entry was logged (compare `JsonLog` output).
- Arrays should be stored in the same way, but with values having shape `(n_steps, *array_shape)`.
- `netket.stats.Stats` are essentially dataclasses with the fields `mean`, `variance`, `error_of_mean`, `tau_corr`, `R_hat`. For a stats object, the log file should contain a group containing each field as a separate dataset (and an `iters` field like above).

NetKet stores network parameters as JAX pytrees with leaves being complex-valued or real-valued arrays. The `HDF5Log` should store a flattened version (as returned by `netket.jax.tree_ravel`) in a single dataset of shape `(n_steps, n_parameters)`.

Here is an example layout, showing what a resulting HDF5 log file should contain after 1001 logging steps for a network with 256 variational parameters:
```
Name                            Data type       Shape
# network parameters:
/parameters/iters               int             (1001,)
/parameters/values              complex128      (1001, 256)
# an entry of `log_data` called `Energy` of type `netket.stats.Stats`
/data/Energy/iters              int             (1001,)
/data/Energy/mean               complex128      (1001,)
/data/Energy/error_of_mean      float64         (1001,)
/data/Energy/variance           float64         (1001,)
/data/Energy/tau_corr           float64         (1001,)
/data/Energy/R_hat              float64         (1001,)
# an entry of `log_data` called `S_x` of type `netket.stats.Stats`
/data/S_x/iters                 int             (1001,)
/data/S_x/mean                  complex128      (1001,)
/data/S_x/error_of_mean         float64         (1001,)
/data/S_x/variance              float64         (1001,)
/data/S_x/tau_corr              float64         (1001,)
/data/S_x/R_hat                 float64         (1001,)
# an entry of `log_data` called `acceptance` of type `float64`
/data/acceptance/iters          int             (1001,)
/data/acceptance/values         float64         (1001,)
```

Note that for a normal `netket.VMC` run, there is a lot of redundancy in the `.../iters` arrays (as they will all be equal and of the form `[0, 1, ..., n_steps - 1]`). We accept this overhead both for compatibility with the existing `JsongLog` and for the added flexibility it provides for custom logging at subsets of steps.

bounties.name: Use colors to signal sampling issues in expectation values
bounties.title: Use colors to signal bad sampling in expectation value/samplers state
bounties.body:
[This issue is part of [UnitaryHack](https://unitaryhack.dev/) and comes with a bounty of 50$]

# Context

Currently NetKet has a class, `nk.stats.Stats`, which is used to report expectation values, their error, and some convergence estimators:
```
>>> expval = vs.expect(ha)
>>> type(expval)
<class 'netket.stats.mc_stats.Stats'>
>>> expval
-25.4893 ± 0.0054 [σ²=0.0292, R̂=1.0058]
>>> expval.
expval.R_hat          expval.error_of_mean  expval.mean           expval.tau_corr       expval.variance
```

this same structure is used to show some information during VMC optimisation inside of a tqdm progress bar:
```
➜ python -i Examples/Ising1d/ising1d_sr.py
 31%|██          | 92/300 [00:04<00:09, 22.00it/s, Energy=-25.4866 ± 0.0053 [σ²=0.0281, R̂=1.0129]]
```

Often, users do not notice that `R_hat>1.01` and therefore sampling is going bad. It would be useful if we could detect this and print `R̂=1.0129` with a color that depends on it's value: white/green if it's close to 1, orange/red the farther it gets. 

This same colouring should be used to show colors inside of the progress bar used by the VMC optimisation.

This same colouring mechanism could be used in the method used to print the acceptance rate of MetropolisSamplerState, when It becomes very small.
```
>>> vs.sampler_state
MetropolisSamplerState(# accepted = 15218/52160 (29.175613496932517%), rng state=[516607177 138071688])
``` 

An exmple implementation should lead to something like this:
[![asciicast](https://asciinema.org/a/hWGiJzJvJAJTxl0y6kljbrBd8.svg)](https://asciinema.org/a/hWGiJzJvJAJTxl0y6kljbrBd8)


# Implementation Note:

One possible implementation, already sketched in PR #1098, is to use the beautiful [textualize/Rich](https://github.com/Textualize/rich) package to define custom representation methods of python's objects using a `__rich__` method instead of `__repr__`. 

Chosing this implementation would also involve moving to Rich's progresss bar our VMC/AbstractDriver class, and enabling Rich's rich text output only when using a REPR/iPython/Jupyteer but not when running scripts from the commandline.

(A rich based implementation would be a useful starting point for further utilities in the future, such as more catchy warnings and error messages).
However, other implementation using different packagese are welcome.


##

bounties.name: Support ladder operators in PauliStrings Operators
bounties.title: Ladder operators in PauliStrings
bounties.body:
[This issue is part of [UnitaryHack](https://unitaryhack.dev/) and comes with a bounty of 100$]

**Context**
NetKet implements PauliStrings operators that implement the Pauli matrix sums. For example, one can create an TFIM with 2 spins as
```python
nk.operator.PauliStrings(hilbert, operators=("ZZ", "XI", "IX"), weights=(-J, -h, -h))
```
However, notice that if we would implement ladder operators such as (X+iY)/2, we would need to sum over two terms. This becomes problematic when we implement e.g. Jordan-Wigner transformations which contain ladder operators at multiple sites, such that the number of terms in the sum in the operators blows up. Currently, NetKet therefore implements a custom version of fermionic operators which does the Jordan-Wigner transformation more efficiently. This is clearly not ideal, and there are many more examples where ladder operators become important.

**Implementation notes**
To resolve this issue, we need ladder operators. We can allow the PauliStrings to take strings "+" and "-" for a ladder operator (X+iY)/2 and (X-iY)/2 respectively. The main difference with other Pauli operators (X, Y, Z, I) is that these operators will often generate matrix elements that are zero. Nevertheless, it will avoid the current behavior of NetKet, which regards X and Y separately in the ladder operators. We can of course also extend this to ladder operators that operate on other hilbert space than just Qubit and Spin.

The implementation requires parsing the input strings to detect "+" and "-" gates, and to create connected elements accordingly. More than that, NetKet also allows a researcher to do symbolic manipulations with PauliStrings, and any new type of operator would have to implement this as well. Hence, we need to implement the commutation relations and so on.

Currently, NetKet parses the PauliStrings as follows in order to compute matrix elements for a given set of samples
- X: flips the spin, does not give phase factor
- Y: flips the spin, gives a phase factor
- Z: does not flip the spin, gives a phase factor
- I: does not flip the spin, does not change the phase
We see that we can know in advance which operators affect the "mels" (matrix elements) and which create "connected elements" different from the input element. The "+" and "-" will now need to be parsed as well. However, these now generate 0 matrix elements, and hence, we will need to store the locations of such "ladder operators". Once this is known, we know that it will often happen that the corresponding matrix elements vanish, and that there is therefore not always a connected element for each sample (in contrary to other PauliStrings which always have 1 connected element).

Once we have this implemented, we can do many things like fermionic operators much more efficiently and consistently, which opens up the road to quantum chemistry with NetKet!

bounties.name: Implement single-pass statistics estimators for variance and convergence estimators
bounties.title: Add single-pass online statistics support to `nk.stats.Stats`
bounties.body:
[This issue is part of [UnitaryHack](https://unitaryhack.dev/) and comes with a bounty of 75$]

**Context**
In NetKet we want to extract some statistical informations from an estimator, such as mean, variance, error of mean as well as convergence indicators such as `correlation time` and `R_hat`.

The standard way to do that is through the `netket.stats.statistics` function in the `netket.stats` submodule.
This function takes as input a set of `M` chains of `N` samples of a random scalar variables, passed as an `MxN` matrix of real or complex numbers.

The function returns a `netket.stats.Stats` object, which is a (frozen) python dataclass which stores the three quantities mentioned before:
 - Mean
 - Error of Mean
 - Variance
 - $\hat{R}$ or split-$\hat{R}$ (see https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.08008 )
 - average autocorrelation time per-chain 

For example:
```python
>>> import netket as nk
>>> import jax
>>> data = jax.random.normal(jax.random.PRNGKey(0), (10, 10000))
>>> nk.stats.statistics(data)
-0.0015 ± 0.0031 [σ²=0.9978, R̂=1.0001]
>>> stats = nk.stats.statistics(a)
>>> stats
-0.0015 ± 0.0031 [σ²=0.9978, R̂=1.0001]
>>> stats.tau_corr
DeviceArray(0., dtype=float64)
```

If one splits the dataset A along the chains obtaining two sets of `M` chains each having `N/2` samples, it is currently not possible to be able to combine their respective `Stats` objects into a single one.
Essentially, we would like to be able to do the following:
```python
>>> A = data[:,:10000/2]
>>> B = data[:, 10000/2:]
>>> stats_A = nk.stats.statistics(A)
>>> stats_B = nk.stats.statistics(B)
>>> stats_AUB = stats_A.append_statsistics(stats_B)
>>> assert stats_AUB ~~ stats
``` 

Assumptions that should be made is that you can append the `Stats` object to an existing `Stats` object, and chains are correlated among themselves.

## Implementation detail

Right now the `Stats` object is an empty box containing 5 floating variables. 
To support appending (aka, Online or single-pass statistics) you will need to store some additional variables. 
For example, to support single-pass variance computation you would need to store both the mean of the random variable $X$,  $\mathbb{E}[X]$ and the expectation value of the square $\mathbb{E}[X^2]$, then the two can be combined because

$$
C = A\cup B
$$

$$
\mathbb{V}ar[X]_C = \mathbb{E}[X]_C^2 -  \mathbb{E}[X^2]_C
$$

and then the expectation values can be combined individually (assuming the blocks have the same length.

$$
\mathbb{E}[X]_C = \frac{\mathbb{E}[X]_A  + \mathbb{E}[X]_B}{2}
$$

Your task should be to implement a mechanism to do this not only for variance, but also for $\hat{R}$ and autocorrelation time, for example by doing block-FFT or some different estimator.

The function should be able to run under `jax.jit`.

The function should be well tested and pass existing as well as new unit tests.

## Additional Information

A simple, buggy, implementation can be found in the branch of this PR https://github.com/netket/netket/pull/824 and in particular in [this file](https://github.com/netket/netket/blob/cfaff7cea67518b64f015d7fba5bf8e691612185/netket/stats/stats_base.py) which works for variance.

Additional inspiration can be drawn from the https://github.com/joshday/OnlineStats.jl Julia package (which implements exactly the algorithm we are interested in).

bounties.name: Setting qutip-qip as an optional package for qutip-5
bounties.title: Setting `qutip-qip` as an optional package for qutip-5
bounties.body:
### Problem Description

From version 5.0, the subpackage `qutip.qip` will be removed and replaced by a separate package `qutip-qip`. To make it easier for others to migrate from 4.7 to 5.0, we can set up `qutip-qip` as an optional plug-in for qutip, so that if `qutip-qip` is installed, the `qutip.qip` name space can be used as before.

### Expected behaviour
- If only `qutip` is installed, importing `qutip.qip` will raise an `ImportError` with instruction for installing `qutip_qip`.
- If `qutip-qip` is installed, using `qutip.qip` will automatically use the `qutip_qip` namespace, with no difference in the user interface.
- Update `setup.cfg` so that `pip install qutip[qip]` will automatically install `qutip_qip`.

E.g. the following should work if `qutip`-5.0 and `qutip-qip` are both installed
```python
# The following should be the same
from qutip.qip.circuit import QubitCircuit
from qutip_qip.circuit import QubitCircuit
```


### Proposed Solution

See https://github.com/qutip/qutip/discussions/1500 for ideals on the implementation.

**Note: The implementation should be done against the `dev.major` branch of qutip.**

bounties.name: Set up towncrier for managing the changelog
bounties.title: Set up towncrier for managing the changelog.
bounties.body:
### Problem Description

Currently the most time consuming part of making releases is managing the change log (#1055 , #1108, #1533). In addition to the time taken, the release manager is often poorly placed to write change log entries for the PRs involved (the PRs might have been merged some time ago, and the release manager might not have been the author).

### Proposed Solution

[Towncrier](https://pypi.org/project/towncrier/) is a Python package used by Python itself and many other libraries to manage the change log.

I propose that we configure towncrier and ensure that each PR adds a towncrier entry.

This includes:
- [ ] Add suitable towncrier configuration to the respository.
- [ ] Update the release documentation with instructions for using towncrier to update the change log.
- [ ] Update the development documentation to include the requirement to add towncrier entries for each PR.
- [ ] Update the GitHub PR template to mention the requirement to add a towncrier entry.
- [ ] Add a check to the GitHub action tests workflow that checks that a towncrier entry was added.

### Alternate Solutions

There are a few other tools that do similar things to towncrier, and we could use one of those instead if they are better.

I would recommend that we not roll our own solution. The problem is fairly simple, but writing and documenting our own solution and fixing the inevitable bugs is a lot of work. Plus, I would prefer to have a solution that has already made choices that work, rather than us having to make all of those choices ourselves.

### Additional Context

_No response_

bounties.name: Implement graphical fourier transform and inverse
bounties.title: Implement graphical fourier transform and inverse
bounties.body:
Implement the graphical Fourier transform, and its inverse. This would allow converting back and forth between ZX and ZH diagrams.

See the paper: [Graphical Fourier Theory and the Cost of Quantum Addition](https://arxiv.org/abs/1904.07551).

A subtle point when working with ZH diagrams in pyzx: the pyzx `Graph` data structure does not support parallel edges. However, sometimes parallel edges are unavoidable between H-boxes. As a result, some care should be taken in how rewrites involving H-boxes are implemented to work around this (e.g. by introducing an identity-spider on one of the edges).

bounties.name: Additional convenience features for the d3 drawing of diagrams
bounties.title: Additional convenience features for the d3 drawing of diagrams
bounties.body:
I suggest two new features for the d3 drawing of diagrams (using zx.draw()):

* When two spiders significantly overlap, there should be some kind of visual indication that allows you to easily see this. For instance, a number in a bright color indicating the number of spiders overlapping, and/or some kind of warning symbol.
* The ability to zoom in and out on a diagram, either by ctrl-scrolling, or by having +/- buttons displayed on the d3 window, whichever turns out to work best.
* If this is possible in Jupyter, the ability to make the display window smaller or bigger in order to show a larger or smaller part of the diagram.

bounties.name: Document features that currently have no documentation
bounties.title: Document features that currently have no documentation
bounties.body:
Over the years, several additional features have been merged into PyZX that have never had documentation written for them. These include:
* CNOT circuit routing, as implemented in the `pyzx.routing` subfolder by @Aerylia.
* The handling of mixed classical-quantum circuits, as implemented by @ABorgna.
* Simplification of diagrams using genetic algorithms, as implemented in the `pyzx.local_search` subfolder by Ryan Krueger.

For unitaryHACK, it would be great if someone were to document one or more of these features.

bounties.name: Better rust bindings/integration
bounties.title: Better rust bindings/integration
bounties.body:
This issue has to do with integrating (better) with [quizx](https://github.com/Quantomatic/quizx), the Rust port of pyzx.

There are already some python bindings, available [here](https://github.com/Quantomatic/quizx/tree/master/pybindings), but they only cover some of the functionality. This request is to extend the coverage of quizx functionality and also make quizx and it's python bindings pip-installable.

bounties.name: Refactor commutative analysis
bounties.title: CommutationAnalysis needs to be refactored
bounties.body:
in 2018, #1500 introduced `CommutationAnalysis` pass. The pass does the trick while working with `CommutativeCancellation`. However, there are some aspects that are not very well covered and I think it is time to sit again with it and think it over again. Here there are a list of the problems:

## property `commutation_set` is a messy dict

The property `property_set['commutation_set']` is a non-uniformly typed dict:
```python
from qiskit import QuantumCircuit

circuit = QuantumCircuit(1)
circuit.h(0)

from qiskit.transpiler.passes import CommutationAnalysis

property_set = {}
CommutationAnalysis()(circuit, property_set)

for k,v in property_set['commutation_set'].items():
    print(type(k), type(v))
```
```
<class 'qiskit.circuit.quantumregister.Qubit'> <class 'list'>
<class 'tuple'> <class 'int'>
<class 'tuple'> <class 'int'>
<class 'tuple'> <class 'int'>
```

**suggested solution**: `property_set['commutation_set']` should be a `qiskit.dagcircuit.dagdependency.DAGDependency`.

## does not handle intransitivity

The current commutation analysis assumes transitivity (I think), while the relation is intransitive. For example `H` commutes with `I`  and `I` commutes with `Z`, but `H` does not commute with `Z`. This is not reflected in the commutative set:

```python
from qiskit.circuit import Qubit
from qiskit.dagcircuit import DAGOpNode

def pp_commutation_set(property_commutation_set):
    # pretty printer of the commutation set
    for qbit, sets in property_commutation_set.items():
        if not isinstance(qbit, Qubit):
            continue
        print(qbit.index)
        for commutation_set in sets:
            r=[]
            for node in commutation_set:
                if isinstance(node, DAGOpNode):
                    r.append(f"{node.op.name}_{node._node_id}{[arg.index for arg in node.qargs]}")
            if r:
                print('\t', r)

from qiskit import QuantumCircuit

circuit = QuantumCircuit(1)
circuit.h(0)
circuit.id(0)
circuit.z(0)

from qiskit.transpiler.passes import CommutationAnalysis

property_set = {}
CommutationAnalysis()(circuit, property_set)

pp_commutation_set(property_set['commutation_set'])
```
```
0
	 ['h_2[0]', 'id_3[0]', 'z_4[0]']
```

## There is a lot of duplication with `DAGDependency`

The `qiskit.dagcircuit.dagdependency.DAGDependency` seems to do the same as `qiskit.transpiler.passes.optimization.commutation_analysis.CommutationAnalysis`. For example [`qiskit.dagcircuit.dagdependency._does_commute`](https://github.com/Qiskit/qiskit-terra/blob/a735680f69f7a2e2757dddbedf09f6d7c6a5e692/qiskit/dagcircuit/dagdependency.py#L570) and [`qiskit.transpiler.passes.optimization.commutation_analysis._commute`](https://github.com/Qiskit/qiskit-terra/blob/3763e61f16f97598cb0fa317277ad85fa15db738/qiskit/transpiler/passes/optimization/commutation_analysis.py#L117) are similar in their goal, but one of them has a cache system that makes it better.

bounties.name: Template library needs to be reorganized
bounties.title: template library organization
bounties.body: The template circuits used in the template optimization pass are currently stored in a directory under `qiskit.circuit.library.templates`. It would be better to store them in a proper library structure like the EquivalenceLibrary, where each entry in the library can be verified for correctness.

bounties.name: Improve type hinting
bounties.title: Make type hinting mypy-clean with relaxed settings
bounties.body:
It's not clear that we want to enforce strict type hinting for qiskit and/or include mypy in our CI, but I do think that for the places where type hinting exists, there those hints should aim to be correct. For many modules they mostly already are, but in others there are a lot of errors. I'd even be fine with removing the incorrect type hints if its too much trouble to correct them.

The current situation makes it harder for contributors who care to use mypy since they need to ignore all the errors that don't relate to their PR.

bounties.name: Arbitrary order in circuit drawers
bounties.title: arbitrary order in circuit drawers
bounties.body:
### What should we add?

Circuit drawers currently have `reverse_bits`, as an option to modify the order in which wires are represented. @ajavadia suggests a generalized version of that feature: `wire_order`. This parameter might define the order of the wires `draw(..., wire_order=[3,0,2,1])` and can eventually replace `reverse_bits` with `draw(..., wire_order='reverse'`.

bounties.name: Fix "back" button of most of browsers
bounties.title: Fix "back" button of most of browsers
bounties.body:
Sometimes the "go back" button of the browser is not working, and we cannot figure out why. 
This is how to reproduce the bug.

- Click on Section 2.4.4 from the left menu (i.e. [https://quantumalgorithms.org/chapter-intro.html#modified-hadamard-test](here) )
- Scroll to the bottom of the page
- Click reference C.8 in the appendix
- Press go back in your browser. 

In Safari, pressing back won't bring you to the end of the page. 

Any idea on how to fix this is appreciated.

bounties.name: Edit .css to make the website more readable
bounties.title: Edit .css to make the website more readable
bounties.body: We need some help in modifying the css, so to make the website more readable. There are three modifications that would be nice to have, with two screenshots at the end of this issue for better illustrating the problem. 1) The color of the Parts of the book should be changed. I would suggest the blue color of the box of definitions (see box 2.7 of constant function for instance). For example, the string "I - Bridging the gap " should be more visible. 2) The size of the left menu bar is fixed, and perhaps too small. Because of this, it is not possible to fully read titles o the chapters. Can we increase the size of the menu on the left, and make it resizable with the mouse? 3) The buttons "go to previous chapter" and "go to next chapter" are currently transparent, and when they overlap the rest of the text, they hide it. Can we make the buttons in the image below darker, so it's clear when they overlap with the text? If you decide to start this issue and you want some clarification or help, just contact me (@Scinawa ) on the discord of the unitary.fund, the slack channel of QOSF, @scinawa on twitter, or write me at ale@nus.edu.sg. In the first image, the three points discussed above. In the second image and example of the problem with the "right" and "left" buttons. ![example](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2940017/167347024-f85b8669-9240-456e-8f13-64c4c676163d.png) Thank you!

bounties.name: Work on error propagation section in appendices
bounties.title: Work on error propagation section in appendices
bounties.body:
It would be very nice to improve the section on error propagation from the point of view of theoretical computer science. 

To date, I was not able to find a nice place where to learn error propagation in algorithms. 

There are many places on the internet that discuss this, but most of them are taking the approach of a physicists that needs to run an experiment (https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/jres/70C/jresv70Cn4p263_A1b.pdf ).  This is not really helpful for CS people, as the error propagation in CS is different.

We have some notes to share (here in the repository, commented in the code) as we are half-way through this part. 

- How to go from relative error to absolute error and vice versa
- Propagation of error in function of one variable (and their proof) for relative and absolute cases. For example (and this is already commented in the 
- Propagation of error in function of multiple variable
- The general case: the mean value theorem.  ( https://www.onemathematicalcat.org/CalculusBook/MainBook/4_9MVT.pdf or any book in calcolus, https://homepage.divms.uiowa.edu/~atkinson/ftp/ENA_Materials/Overheads/sec_2-3.pdf, and much more..)


If you decide to start this issue and you want some clarification or help, just contact me (@Scinawa ) on the discord of the unitary.fund, the slack channel of QOSF, @Scinawa on twitter, or write me at [ale@nus.edu.sg](mailto:ale@nus.edu.sg).

bounties.name: Finish section on concentration inequalities
bounties.title: Finish section on concentration inequalities
bounties.body:
We would like to have a proper part on the concentration inequalities. 

This is very important in computer science and in algorithms analysis because the runtime and the errors are bounded using tools like these. In particular, it would be very nice to collect all the useful formulations for Chernoff bound and Hoeffding, Bernstein inequality, law or large numbers, union bound, central limit theorem, their proofs, and some simple but important applications in the quantum domain. 

Are there other concentration inequality that we should include? Let's discuss!

I have collected quite a lot of material on the subject: 

- https://www.probabilitycourse.com/chapter6/6_2_3_chernoff_bounds.php ( I like a lot the Comparison between Markov, Chebyshev, and Chernoff Bounds) 
- http://www.stat.rice.edu/~jrojo/PASI/lectures/TyronCMarticle.pdf
- https://yassine-hamoudi.github.io/files/other/PhDthesis.pdf (the preliminaries )
- https://twitter.com/zlatko_minev/status/1521108505247326210/photo/1 
- Dubhashi, Panconesi - 2009 - Concentration of measure for the analysis of randomized algorithms  (they have very good explanations and proofs)

If you decide to start this issue and you want some clarification or help, just contact me (@Scinawa ) on the discord of the unitary.fund, the slack channel of QOSF, @Scinawa on twitter, or write me at [ale@nus.edu.sg](mailto:ale@nus.edu.sg).

bounties.name: Macro for snapping refpoints
bounties.title: Macro for snapping refpoints
bounties.body:
Would be cool if in GUI workflow one could snap refpoints to other. For example one might select refpoint 1 which belongs to PCell 1, then refpoint 2 which belongs to PCell 2, then runs a "snapping macro" which moves PCell 1 such that refpoints 1 and 2 would match. Waveguides would be special - instead of moving the PCell, only the node would move.

Proposed workflow:
1) you loosely place elements and waveguides 
2) you select elements
3) you run the macro 
4) the macro goes over all elements in the order of selection
5) it checks if the element in question has any refpoints of other elements later in the queue in vicinity of refpoints of present element, within customizable "snapping radius"
6) if there is, the macro moves the second element such that the refpoints would match

Note that there is already code in https://github.com/iqm-finland/KQCircuits/blob/main/klayout_package/python/scripts/macros/export/export_cells_as_code.lym and https://github.com/iqm-finland/KQCircuits/blob/main/klayout_package/python/kqcircuits/util/layout_to_code.py for printing out code that creates snapped elements based on loosely placed elements. The difference in this new macro would be that it moves cells existing in layout instead of printing code.

bounties.name: produce_waveguide_to_port does not infer side for EdgePort
bounties.title: `produce_waveguide_to_port` does not infer side for EdgePort
bounties.body:
I noticed that [`produce_waveguide_to_port`](https://github.com/iqm-finland/KQCircuits/blob/main/klayout_package/python/kqcircuits/simulations/simulation.py) does not infer the side to extend to when using `use_internal_ports=False`, i.e., EdgePort. It has to be given with the `side` param.
Supporting `side=None` to extend the simulation in the direction most indicated by `towards` is a natural choice I think.

bounties.name: Links to files in documentation
bounties.title: Links to files in documentation
bounties.body:
The docs occasionally refer to specific files in repository, such as, this paragraph in [Geometry from Klayout GUI](https://iqm-finland.github.io/KQCircuits/user_guide/export/simulation_export.html#geometry-from-klayout-gui):

> Alternatively, run following macros in Klayout:
>* `scripts/macros/export/export_ansys.lym`
>* `scripts/macros/export/export_sonnet.lym`

It would be nice if these were links to the files in `main` on GitHub. The `|GIT_CLONE_URL|` substitution [already exists](https://github.com/iqm-finland/KQCircuits/blob/09ef6c7198fb88c4084b4dbb13948e755b4b8c4a/docs/conf.py#L174), so it can probably be used to implement this.

bounties.name: super().build() always needed in chips
bounties.title: `super().build()` always needed in chips
bounties.body:
At the end of each chip's `build()` method we must always remember to call `super().build()` because `Chip.build()` creates some geometry that is needed in all chips. It would be better if that was not needed.

Proposed solution is to use a new `post_build()` method that is always automatically called in `Element.produce_impl()`:

- [ ] Add empty `post_build()` method to Element
- [ ] Call `self.post_build()` in `Element.produce_impl()` after `self.build()`
- [ ] Rename `Chip.build()` to `Chip.post_build()`
- [ ] Remove `super().build()` call from all chips. 

The `post_build()` method of elements could later be used also for other actions that are needed after `build()`.

bounties.name: Macro for generating a list of refpoints from all hierarchy levels
bounties.title: Macro for generating a list of refpoints from all hierarchy levels
bounties.body: To help users get a better understanding of refpoints, we could have a KLayout macro that prints out a list of all refpoints in the layout. The output should be formatted so that the hierarchy of the refpoints/cells is clear. See https://iqm-finland.github.io/KQCircuits/user_guide/python_workflow.html#refpoints for an explanation about refpoints.

bounties.name: Manual steps in code refresh
bounties.title: Manual steps in code refresh
bounties.body:
If I edit a PCell source code and want to see the changes within KLayout application, I need to:
1. run [Reload libraries](https://github.com/iqm-finland/KQCircuits/blob/main/klayout_package/python/scripts/macros/reload.lym) macro
2. make a new copy of a PCell

Would be nice if there was one less manual step and I would not need to make a new PCell. Instead:
1. before reloading, the reload macro could extract the PCell information in the active layout 
2. removes the PCell instance
3. reloads the libraries
4. places instances of the PCells with same parameters and location

Maybe after this issue we should have the follow up features:

5. watchdog for code changes to autorefresh such that I would not even need to run refresh macro manually
6. partial refresh to refresh a single python module and corresponding PCell, not the full library (the changed PCell might be inside other PCells)

bounties.name: Point-and-click workflow tutorial outdated
bounties.title: Point-and-click workflow tutorial outdated
bounties.body:
With new KLayout and KQCircuits versions some things have changed so that parts of ["point-and-click" workflow tutorial](https://iqm-finland.github.io/KQCircuits/user_guide/gui_workflow.html) don't work as described or are confusing. At least:

- Part 4.4-5.4: Not easy to select qubit because waveguide cells are selected instead.
	* Alternative way to select a qubit is to drag a selection box around it. Pressing "q" can then be used to open the "object properties" window.
- Part 6.5: The button is now a magnifying glass instead of "...".
	* Can mention both, so that both older and new KLayout versions can be used
- Part 7.1: Ground grid is not visible by default, should tell to unhide it in the layers list.

The end result should be such that everything works when following exactly the instructions in the tutorial.
